metadata.synopsis: With help from an orphaned pickpocket (Kim Tae-ri), a Korean con man (Ha Jung-woo) devises an elaborate plot to seduce and bilk a Japanese woman (Kim Min-hee) out of her inheritance.

reviews: The drama combines the sumptuous art direction and black humor of Park's past work with a warmth and compassion that feeds the soul.
A complicated revenge story, ripe with detail and secrets.
The Handmaiden is an epic illustration that there is perhaps nothing more human than inhumanity.
The twists in The Handmaiden come fast and furious. It's an engrossing tale that will constantly have you guessing which direction the narrative is headed.
Plenty of humor and an incomparably depraved, unyielding, violent, rebellious level of creativity.
...the love between the two lead women is what drives this film.
Throbbing with greed and passion, deception and betrayal, the story remains every bit as gripping on screen as it was on the page.
A rapturously seductive slow burn watch.
"[Park]'s clearly a believer in the Roger Ebert school of thought, which favors appreciation over deconstruction."
"[Park]'s clearly a believer in the Roger Ebert school of thought, which favors appreciation over deconstruction."
After witnessing this spectacle of eroticism and betrayal, we officially confirm that there is Park Chan-wook's cinema for a while. [Full review in Spanish]
The Handmaiden is ambitious, hypnotic, and elegantly constructed, even with all of its countless twists and misdirections.
A consuming love story blessing its audience with a memorable erotic scene involving a sharp tooth and a thimble.
As we discover its twists and turns, the movie proves to be a much less interesting story than it seemed to be in its wonderful first act. [Full Review in Spanish]
The result is enticingly giddy in its psychological corruption, both of the characters - it's a standard gas-lighting plot - and of audience expectation.
This entertaining potboiler manages to satisfy those in the mood for a historically compelling escapist yarn.
The visual design of The Handmaiden is itself borderline pornographic- which makes the movie pretty impossible to dislike.
Park Chan-wook crafts a mysterious, imaginative, and stylish to a fault feature that defies expectations and ranks among the year's finest.
Intertwines lustful carnal scenes and tense artful schemes.

It's a film that gradually reveals its many layers of deception, is always visually stunning, yet drops one of the most intriguing deceits of the original novel and its new third part where loose ends are tied up seems rather abrupt.
